comment.author: 38401430@N06

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/jackleisen] Uploaded this image in fun. Sorry that you found it offensive. However I am baffled at your definition of Leprechaun. Have never heard of this definition. It is actually a very ancient Irish word and appears in the 1817 supplement to O'Reilly's Irish Dictionary as "In Irish folk-lore, A pigmy sprite ‘who always carries a purse containing a shilling’ ". These are examples of 17th century usage from the Oxford English Dictionary: 1620 T. Dekker Dreame sig. D3, Mounted on a Spirits back, which ran With Mandrake-shrikes, and like a Lubrican. 1627 M. Drayton Nimphidia in Battaile Agincovrt 127 By the Mandrakes dreadfull groanes; By the Lubricans sad moanes. 1630 T. Dekker Second Pt. Honest Whore sig. E3, As for your Irish Lubrican, that spirit Whom by prepostrous charmes thy lust hath raised In a wrong Circle. And again, from the very reliable Oxford English Dictionary an etymology of the word Leprechaun:
"Written lupracán, lugharcán, lugracán, in O'Reilly Irish. Dict. Suppl.; in the body of the Dict. it is spelt leithbrágan, doubtless by etymologizing perversion, the sprite being ‘supposed to be always employed in making or mending a single shoe’ (leith half, bróg brogue); O'Reilly also gives luacharman as a synonym. In some mod. Irish books the spelling lioprachán occurs. All these forms may be corrupted from one original; compare Middle Irish luchrupán (Windisch Gloss.), altered form of Old Irish luchorpán (Stokes in Revue Celtique I. 256), lu small + corp body."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Abstract: Leprosy and Leper Hospitals in Late Medieval Ireland Going off at a tangent, this brings up the history of leprosy in Ireland. I have been puzzled by the numerous isolated places called "Pity Me" in Northumberland and County Durham. The larger "Pity Me" just north of Durham City is usually said to have been derived from Norman French "Petite Mere", but I don't accept this. Are there any places called "Pity Me" in Ireland? Maybe they are not in the OSI gazetteer. Is there a connection with the old leper hospitals?

comment._content: Citybus from Donegal Sq West, you want the stop before Sydenham Train Station but after Connsbrook Avenue and if you reach Tesco's at Knocknagoney you've gone too far !!

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
Given that I used to live just off the Old Holywood Road at Cairnburn, I know the area well! I have the sore back from the Citybus "bouncing" Leyland Tigers with leaf springs on Cairnburn Road!

When my grandfather used to read things out when I was a young child, if he came to a word he didn't recognise or couldn't pronounce he used to say "a big house on the Holywood Road"  instead of the word. When I asked what he meant he used to reply " well it's a big word like Knocknagoney" (ie 3 syllables I guess?).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Should I be searching for "a big house on the Holywood Road" to put up here in honour of your grandfather?  :)

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Yes that is my grandfather! The photo was taken at Belfast Harbour where he was a crane driver (a fact verified by the 1911 census when he was aged 21 and shown as such). It seems that 3 of these cranes remain (albeit semi-derelict on the dockside) and have been linked to the building of the Titanic.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: I can confirm they are still  there, sounds like your Grandfather would have worked on the Titanic himself.

comment.author: 29492435@N02

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] "Knocknagoney sounds so romantic???"  Carol is a woman (in case you hadn't noticed) and women are suckers for anything romantic, so I thought that it was an opportunity to get Billh35 something he wanted;-0

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: maps.google.co.uk/maps?q=bt4+2pp&hl=en&ll=54.6186... This is Knocknagoney House which now belongs to PSNI and is next door to Tescos! It is this which is the famous "big house on the Holywood Road". My grandfather worked for Belfast Harbour Commissioners rather than Harland & Wolff and these cranes were BHC owned. However, I have seen references to cranes like these being used on the Titanic. He NEVER spoke about the Titanic - it was like they were ashamed of what had happened. I'd love to know if Crane No. 32 is one of the ones still there though! Where's Gerry when I need him!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] Having seen the Google Street view of Knocknagoney house all references to "Romantic" are hereby withdrawn, unless you're a "peeler" of course?

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
This place used to be a vehicle store and in the very early days of The Troubles "local youths" broke in and vandalised ALL the RUC Humber Pig riot control vehicles rendering them inoperable. Now for those that don't know, this is what would be termed a "loyalist" area so no Provos around here - the only thing worse is that they broke into a Police Station!!!!!!!!!!!! What does that say about security?

Just how far off topic can we get with this?

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Beside the "Big House" used to be the  Orchard caravans sales site they had holiday sites in Ballycastle and Castlerock now owned by Hayes Caravans of Dunganon ........... err hows that for off topic?

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] I have some photos of these three cranes, the third is to the left of the two in the photo, but they are so badly rusted, and I assume have had replacement panels fitted over the last 100yrs, that I can not see anything to identify any of them as crane 32. You are welcome to the photos if you want them.
